report_title: Car & Automobile Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry has had a bumpy road over the five years to 2022. Declining prices for fuel and crude oil over the past decade have helped bolster demand for trucks and sport utility vehicles at the expense of compact cars and sedans. Furthermore, automakers' response to changing consumer preferences has been to shift production away from industry-relevant vehicles. As a result, industry revenue has suffered during the period, while the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated industry decline trends. Industry revenue will likely decline an annualized 2.3% to $100.9 billion over the five years to 2022, despite an anticipated 2.6% increase in 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Declining oil prices during much of the period has helped shift consumer preferences away from compact cars and sedans. As demand for industry-relevant vehicles declined, manufacturers have begun to alter production schedules, focusing higher percentages of production on trucks and neglecting cars.

The COVID-19 pandemic stifled macroeconomic activity across the United States, leading to reduced demand for automobiles. Many industry companies opted to temporarily idle plants. As a result, industry revenue will likely decline an annualized 2.3% to $100.9 billion over the five years to 2022.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2027, industry revenue is expected to return to growth as confidence in the economy returns and consumers are more inclined to make expensive discretionary purchases like vehicles. However, rising inflation and interest rates could harm the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Continued shift away from industry products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Automakers are still expected to shift production to focus on light trucks, placing further downward pressure on industry revenue for compact cars and sedans.

industry_definition: Companies in the Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry manufacture cars and automobile chassis. These operators, which are referred to as automakers, typically produce cars, including electric cars, in assembly plants. The manufacturing of light trucks (e.g. vans, pickups and SUVs), heavy trucks and motorcycles is excluded from this industry.
key_trends: A plunging economy in 2020 has accelerated the decline in industry revenue
While low gasoline prices generally aid industry operators, they may also shift consumer tastes
Operators have made a concerted effort to reduce wages and improve efficiency
Consumers are expected to be more likely to purchase big-ticket goods, such as vehicles
More closures of plants that produce industry-relevant vehicles may occur

market_segmentation.segment_description: A significant portion of vehicles produced in the United States are shipped abroad. 35.3% of exported industry goods are destined to Canada, in large part due to the USMCA making trade with the United States' neighbor relatively simple.
Automobile dealerships are expected to account for 24.8% of revenue in 2022. Dealers sell the clear majority of their vehicles directly to consumers.

Wholesalers are the largest domestic market segment of this industry and are expected to account for 24.5% of industry revenue in 2022. Wholesalers buy large volumes of identical vehicles from automakers.
Commercial clients are expected to account for 3.4% of industry revenue in 2022.
Vehicle leasing companies, including automaker subsidiaries and independent companies, lease vehicles to consumers and businesses used as either commercial vehicles or rentals for day-to-day use.
Government agencies, including local and federal law enforcement, account for 2.0% of revenue in 2022.

products_and_services.product_description: They offer exceptional fuel economy, but offer limited legroom and smaller engine options. Most cars in this segment come with four-cylinder engines, although six-cylinder V6 engines are available as well.

Demand for this segment over the five years to 2022 has been supported by high gas prices early during the period, which prompted consumers to prefer midsize, more fuel-efficient cars rather than large cars or SUVs.

Some automakers specialize in luxury cars. All other automakers produce their luxury cars with significant parts sharing from similar mass-market models. For example, the Ford Fusion shares its chassis and many drivetrain components with the luxury Lincoln MKZ.

Due to the similarity of this segment to the more popular midsize category, it has declined as a share of revenue over the five years to 2022. This is mainly due to high oil prices during much of the period and the growing popularity of crossover vehicles, which do not fall within the scope of this industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fuel prices also have an effect on demand for vehicles, as lower prices at the pump encourage more people to invest in personal or family cars. However, lower fuel prices may also encourage some car buyers to consider SUVs or light trucks, which are not part of this industry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Trade-flow patterns of cars across the United States have grown increasingly complex due to the elimination of trade barriers under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) treaty.

business_locations.location_description: The largest share of establishments for the Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry are located in the Great Lakes region, which accounts for 32.3% of locations in 2022. Some of the largest industry operators, such as General Motors Company (GM), Ford Motor Company (Ford) and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV, all have headquarters located in Michigan, accounting for 6.7% of establishments alone.

The new second-largest automotive hub in the United States is the West Region, accounting for 14.6% of industry establishments in 2022. Many automakers have joint ventures and plants in California due to the facilities being located close to a manufacturing hub. California alone accounts for 11.6% of industry establishments in 2022, the most of any state.
The third-largest automotive hub in the United States is the Southeast region, which accounts for 14.0% of industry locations in 2022. This region is primarily home to Japanese manufacturers.
The third-largest automotive hub in the United States is the Southeast region, which accounts for 14.0% of industry locations in 2022. This region is primarily home to Japanese manufacturers.
The Southwest region has around 11.5% of establishments and around 11% of the population.
The New England region has around 8.5% of establishments and around 4.5% of the population.
The Plains region has the lowest percentage of establishments at around 7%, while its population percentage is around 6.5%.
The Rocky Mountain region has around 6% of establishments and around 4% of the population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Since 2004, the NHTSA has ranked vehicles for risk of rollovers, using a percent-risk rating system. Light trucks and SUVs with a high center of gravity are the most prone to rollover. Since 2006, automakers have advertised vehicle safety ratings with stickers on new vehicles.
An estimated 25.0% of greenhouse gases generated in the United States are attributable to car and truck exhausts, attracting the interest of environmental groups and government agencies.

The Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) regulations for United States automotive manufacturers were first set by Congress in 1975. These regulations were created to help improve the average fuel economy of both cars and light trucks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Manufacturing cars is a capital-intensive enterprise requiring sophisticated manufacturing facilities and robust supply chains.
Prospective automakers need proprietary or licensed vehicle designs and an experienced workforce.
New entrants must comply with strict regulatory standards for safety and environmental concerns, which are subject to periodic revisions.
Brand awareness and image is a major factor for many buyers, in addition to being a significant barrier to entry for any new companies.

basis_points.basis_title: Price, fuel economy, reliability, styling and utility
basis_points.basis_description: Operators in the Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry compete primarily on the basis of price, fuel economy, reliability, styling and utility.
Business customers and consumers place different weights on each trait; businesses tend to emphasize utility and reliability, while consumers are more concerned with price and styling.
Automakers periodically redesign a vehicle's styling, typically every five years, but only occasionally change the vehicle's mechanics.
Each car class has a premium subcategory, resulting in a range of prices.
Over the five years to 2022, business customers and consumers have become increasingly concerned with fuel economy, pushing manufacturers to offer more fuel-efficient options.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top companies account for nearly half the market
concentration_points.concentration_description: The Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry has moderate market share concentration, with the top companies typically accounting for nearly half of the market.

These three automotive hub regions are expected to gain greater concentration over the coming years as operators expand their most successful establishments and shut down those which are not as efficient in other locations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage costs make up the second-largest cost for industry operators, accounting for an estimated 10.7% of revenue in 2022, up from 6.9% in 2017.
Automobile manufacturing requires a large array of components from parts suppliers, ranging from engines and transmissions to radiators and electronics.
Other costs associated with this industry include research and development (R&D) and general machine and building maintenance.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For every $1.00 spent on labor, the average industry operator will invest nearly $0.20 in capital equipment in 2022.
The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the five years to 2022, the Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry has exhibited a high level of revenue volatility, despite a near consistent trend of decline.
In March 2020, the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic began to strongly affect the United States.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While major operators in the Car and Automobile Manufacturing industry have adapted and adopted as quickly as possible to technology.
The largest technological change in industry products has been more widespread availability of green technologies.

FAQs.question: Was your company affected significantly by import competition from abroad during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Companies are heavily affected by demand for imports from abroad, as imports make up a significant share of domestic demand. However, falling import levels in 2020 provided opportunities for domestic automakers to strengthen revenue in local markets.

FAQs.question: How heavily are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy, and how has your revenue trended in response to the effects of COVID-19 on the domestic economy?
FAQs.answer: When the US economy is strong, consumers are more likely to purchase big ticket items at the retail level, which in turn, bolsters demand for vehicles at the upstream manufacturing level. Like most manufacturing industries, operators experienced rapidly diminishing demand for products in 2020 as consumers tightened their belts and stayed at home.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices due to unstable commodity markets troubled by trade interruptions exacerbated by the global spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus)?
FAQs.answer: While declining steel prices generally lower purchase costs for companies to the benefit of profit, many companies were already locked in long-term purchase agreements with suppliers in 2020.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in R&D to meet changing consumer and regulatory preferences?
FAQs.answer: Companies which continued investing in research and development to meet changing consumer vehicle preferences while production slowed in 2020 were able to better prepare for success during forthcoming period as the economy reopened in 2021.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs and meet demand during the pandemic by automating any operations?
FAQs.answer: Companies trying to reduce wage costs through automation long-term were most successful at navigating the pandemic.

FAQs.question: Has your company stayed ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies have to stay ahead of energy-efficiency standards in order to avoid fines and lawsuits.

FAQs.question: What effect have international travel bans implemented to curtail the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus) had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: The majority of trade is with Mexico and Canada, which has somewhat insulated the industry from greater declines in 2020.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is typically a bit lower for passenger vehicles as opposed to SUV and light trucks.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any single market, and have you been able to diversify your customers at all during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Dealerships, wholesalers, rental companies and government agencies all have relationships with automakers typically.

FAQs.question: What supply contracts do you have in place? How have they fared given the widespread supply-chain interruptions periodically caused by the effects of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers need to be able to access parts on a timely basis to ensure the smooth flow of production.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a reputation for good industry relations? How have you kept labor costs low, while providing efficient service during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Work stoppages caused by COVID-19 curtailing efforts were very costly to automakers.

FAQs.question: Is your technical expertise to a world standard? How much does your company invest in innovative technology to enhance day-to-day operations?
FAQs.answer: The degree of investment in technological improvements and product development is important.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly monitor the trade-weighted index? Has the depreciation of the US dollar in the wake of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic affected your company?
FAQs.answer: Exchange rates play an important role in the industry's ability to remain competitive internationally.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the consumer confidence index? Has plummeting confidence in response to poor macroeconomic conditions caused by the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus) affected product demand in recent months?
FAQs.answer: People will generally postpone big-ticket purchases, such as new vehicles, when consumer confidence is low.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor prevailing interest rates? Have you adjusted your promotional strategies as interest rates have tumbled in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Personal income and interest rates determine the price range of a consumer's vehicle purchase and what kind of vehicle a consumer can afford.
